results.title: Asep in action: the student (TEFC)
results.brief_description: Shows students using the unit “Plants” in the classroom and on an excursion, emphasizing the practical aspects of A.S.E.P. courses, whilst participating in excursions, they discus teacher/student relationships, and their feelings about group work and electives.

results.title: As we talk we learn (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Brian Bergin, Malcolm Smith and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Language, specifically talking, is a valuable, perhaps essential element in processes of learning. This film looks at communication between teacher and pupil is necessary in order to maximize the learning process. Various kinds of classroom talking are illustrated in order to determine which is the most effective technique for learning.

results.title: As usual = Sens devant derriere
results.creator_credit: Raymond Brousseau, Monique Letourneau, Paul Larose and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Imagine a world where everything moves backwards. That is what happens in this experimental film without words when a man wakes up to the sound of his alarm clock and begins his day, only to find that for some mysterious reason everything is running in reverse - his electric shaver, the morning paper. Out in the street, people and cars are backing away. He alone of all the crowd seems to move forward normally. The effect on him and the viewers verges on the bizarre. Sound film without commentary.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Raymond Brousseau, Monique Letourneau, Paul Larose and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: As long as I can walk
results.brief_description: A report on a Moratorium March held in Melbourne in 1970. Interviews with marchers give insights into personal motives, and show the strong desire for a peaceful settlement of the Vietnam question.

results.title: Arturo Toscanini
results.creator_credit: United Films and United States. Office of War Information
results.brief_description: Toscannini conducts the NBC Symphony Orchestra in a spirited rendition of Giuseppe Verdi’s “Hymn of the Nations”. With the Westminster Choir, featuring Jan Peerce as soloist, this performance was part of a celebration to mark the liberation of Italy during World War II. The film also sketches the life of Toscannini, showing the way in which he lived up to his convictions. No other credits available.

results.title: Arts of Japan
results.brief_description: This film tells the story of a young American who visits artists of Japan, including the painter Gyokudo Kawai, tea master Soshitsu Sen, actors Koshiro Mataumoto and Manzaburo Umewaka, potter Shoju Hamada, and wood-block artist Shiko Manakata. Includes scenes from the Noh and Kabuki dramas.

results.title: Artists and artisans at Orrefors
results.brief_description: Artists and artisans at work in the Orrefors glass-works in Sweden. We see how they design their work, how they find aesthetic and practical solutions to functional problems, and all stages of the blowing of glass. Artists hand-paint designs onto glass, then they hand-engrave the design to complete the article. Many fine examples of Orrefors glassware are included. No credits available.

results.title: An Artist looks at churches
results.creator_credit: John Taylor, Edgar H. Anstey and British Transport Films
results.brief_description: Out of 20,000 churches in Britain the artist John Piper, selects one from each century from Norman times to the present day. He reveals their riches of architecture, decoration, carving, sculpture and stained glass.

results.title: Artist at work: five British sculptors work and talk (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Warren Forma and Forma Arts Associates
results.brief_description: Shows five British sculptors as they work in their studios and discuss their achievements: Barbara Hepworth, who made the centerpiece for the exterior circle of the United Nations Headquarters in New York; Kenneth Armitage, who made “Mouton sun” for Chateau Mouton Rothschild; Lyn Chadwick, who won first prize in 1959 at Padua; Reg Butler, who won grand prize for his monument of the unknown political prisoner in 1953; Henry Moore, who completed the centerpieces for the Lincoln Centre for the Performing Arts in New York.
